Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impacts of Recent Climate and Emissions Changes on Mercury Bioaccumulation in Arctic Marine Food-Webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to improve our understanding of the factors controlling mercury (Hg) concentrations in the Arctic and their trends over the past three decades (1980-2010). It will develop an atmospheric model for mercury in the Arctic, based on the global GEOS-Chem chemical transport model (CTM) simulation for Hg developed at Harvard, and will be calibrated extensively and evaluated with observations. GEOS-Chem includes dynamical coupling of the atmosphere with surface ocean and land reservoirs. Atmospheric oxidation of Hg(0) to Hg(II), driving Hg(II) deposition, is primarily by bromine (Br) atoms. Model representation of Br chemistry in the Arctic will be tested and improved using recent observations from aircraft and satellites. At all stages of this research, the different model components as well as the coupled model will be evaluated in detail with a large body of atmospheric observations.

The project will produce the first coupled simulation of atmospheric Hg dynamics in the Arctic with the ocean and land components in the existing GEOS-Chem model. This can be a powerful tool for relating changes in anthropogenic emissions and climate to biological Hg concentrations in the Arctic and its strong physical basis will make it a fundamental vehicle to test different hypotheses for Hg cycling and bioaccumulation in the Arctic. Sensitivity analyses using the model will identify areas of greatest uncertainty and help guide future research. This work will enable scientists and policymakers to better assess the impacts of policy decisions aimed at protecting the arctic environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the influence of recent climate variability on mercury concentrations in the Arctic atmosphere and ocean.  Methylmercury, the organic form of mercury, is bioaccumulated in marine organisms and poses health risks to high-fish consuming northern communities and wildlife.  Atmospheric mercury has been measured continuously at a number of Arctic sites since the mid-1990s.  Using a global biogeochemical model (GEOS-Chem), we found that peak Arctic atmospheric mercury concentrations in the summer that are not observed at more southerly latitudes can be explained by enhanced releases of mercury from the Arctic Ocean (Fig 1). These releases match the seasonality of discharges from Arctic rivers, suggesting a high sensitivity of this region to future climate-induced changes mercury releases from the terrestrial environment such as permafrost melt.  This work also investigated sources of interannual variability in mercury in the Arctic atmosphere and ocean using 30-years of meteorological data from NASA to force a coupled ocean-atmosphere model. This work revealed that projected changes in Arctic climate such as increased cloudiness and strong warming in springtime may lead to decreased Hg inputs to the Arctic Ocean (Fig 2).  Ongoing work initiated with support from this project is now investigating how ocean biogeochemistry affects formation and uptake of methylmercury in Arctic food-webs. This work has more broadly contributed to enhanced 3-D atmospheric modeling capabilities for the global community of GEOS-Chem users by developing the capability to run the model using decades (1979-present) of assimilated meteorological data from the NASA-MERRA system.  This research was also used to inform the negotiations of the global Minamata Convention for controlling anthropogenic mercury released led by the United Nations Environment Programme in 2013.  This project contributed to the training of three postdoctoral scholars and two graduate students at Harvard in interdisciplinary environmental modeling, all of whom were women or ethnic minorities.
